page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: The Deene and Deenethorpe district is situated in gently undulating country- side in NE Northamptonshire, an area once covered by the vast Rockingham Forest. The development of this rural area has been strongly influenced by the Brudenell family who have owned much of the land since the 16th century. In a calm and peaceful atmosphere, agriculture-both arable and grazing- provide the major land usage. There are also conifer plantations, disguising redundant iron-ore quarries, a golf course, and a working quarry in the SE of the study area. The district is notable for its large country houses-Deene Hall and Kirby Hall, both open to the public. The local stone villages of Deene and Deenethorpe have declined in size and population in recent years.
